items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message: This is an update to the Flood Alert issued yesterday 21/08/24 at 4:44 PM. The tide in the early hours of tomorrow morning 23/08/24  is expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions and spring tides. Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. The high water level is expected to reach 1.22mAOD at 12:24 AM with southerly force 6 winds. (mAOD is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) Sea spray overtopping along the coast is possible and high water levels in the harbour are forecast. Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff will be closing flood gates if necessary. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.81 mAOD at 06:00 on 23/08/24 and 4.64 mAOD at 18:15 on 23/08/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 15 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 23/08/24, or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding from Storm Lilian has now reduced.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tide on Friday 23rd August. High water at Ilfracombe on Friday evening is at 21:45 BST. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
Force 5 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be around 210mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it;
The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Friday evening is 5.09 mAOD, this is 0.21 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit. The first peak high water level at West Bay Harbour is at 9:00 PM this evening 21/08/24 with a level of 2.50 mAOD with southwesterly force 5 winds. Thursday mornings tide 22/08/24 will not quite reach our threshold for a flood alert,  but tomorrow evenings tide at 9:43PM will exceed threshold with a predicted level of 2.52 mAOD with southwesterly force 5 winds. Tide levels will start dropping from Friday mornings tide onwards. (mAOD is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) Sea spray overtopping along the coast is possible and high water levels in the harbour are forecast. Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. People in the areas should consider taking action now. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary from Liverpool and Wirral to Widnes

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Sefton, Wirral

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast this afternoon, 23/08/2024.   
We do not anticipate the flood alert level to be met during this afternoon’s high tide, but flooding is still possible at low lying lands and roads from 2:45 PM on 23/08/2024 at the following locations:
Rock Park, peaking around 2:45 PM
Hale Village, peaking around 3:15 PM
Flooding of property is not expected.
We currently do not anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 24/08/2024.
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.   
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.   
This message will be updated this afternoon, 23/08/2024, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued because of recent high tides that peaked yesterday evening Thursday 22/08/24. Conditions may apply for an hour either side of high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. 
Predicted peaks.
Newport 7.1m to 7.4m at 22:45 on 23/08/2024. Avonmouth Portbury 7.4 to 7.7m at 22:45 on 23/08/2024.
No thresholds are expected to be crossed on Saturday mornings tide as predicted Spring peaks are now falling.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads that may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 2pm on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
High tides and  strong winds overnight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss at 02:00 AM on 23/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3 hours either side of this time.
Further flooding is possible for the tide at 2:55 AM Saturday 24/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days.
Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss.
We have closed flood gates at St. Georges Quay, Lancaster.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

We do not anticipate the flood alert level to be met during this afternoon’s high tide, but flooding is still possible at low lying lands and roads from 3:45 PM on 23/08/2024 at the following locations:

Eastford Road, peaking around 4:00 PM  
Arpley Bridge, Knutsford Road, and Howley, peaking around 4:15 PM
It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 24/08/2024.
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.  
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.description: Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide this afternoon, 23/08/2024.
We do not anticipate the flood alert level to be met during this afternoon’s high tide, but flooding is still possible at low lying land and roads from Hilbre Island and along the coast from West Kirby to Heswall from 2:30 PM, 23/08/2024.
The current forecast anticipates the flood alert level will not be met during the high tide in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 24/08/2024, however there is still the potential of spray overtopping. 
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 23/08/2024, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 10:15 PM on 22/08/2024 with a level of 7.89 mAODN with southerly force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 10:30 AM on 23/08/2024 with a level of 7.40 mAODN with westerly force 6 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves overnight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 02:15 AM on 23/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3 hours either side of this time.
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Further flooding is possible for the tide at 2:55 AM on Saturday 24/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Friday's early morning tide at 02:30 on 23/08/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with strong South Westerly Force 7 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.2 m. The total forecast tide is 6.22 metres Chart Datum (3.17 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields, including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Friday afternoon's tide at 14:45 on 23/08/2024 is forecast to be 5 cm lower (3.12 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are predicted to continue until Saturday 24/08/2024 for each high tide. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 23/08/2024.

However, the following high tide tonight, which will peak at 2:45 AM on 24/08/24, may result in further flooding. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include the Coastline at Barrow in Furness. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 6:00 PM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between, 14:45 and 16:45, Friday 23 August. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.41mAODN at 15:45, Friday 23 August, which is 0.19m above tide tables, wind Force 4, in a south westerly direction.  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 17:00 today, Friday 23 August.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High tides are expected due to a combination of high spring tides and a storm surge following Storm Lilian. Strong winds may cause large waves within the estuary tomorrow morning, 23/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 05:15 and 07:15, 23/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The area most likely to be affected is Newcastle Quayside.
 
This alert is in force for the this evenings high tide, Thursday (22/08/2024) Friday mornings tide (23/08/2024), and Saturday mornings tide (24/08/24). 
High tides are anticipated between 17:30 and 19:30, 22/08/2024, 05:15 and 07:15, 23/08/2024 and 06:00 and 08:00 24/08/2024. The flood risk impacts will be highest on the Friday morning tide, 23/08/2024. Please remain vigilant for any potential flood warnings around Newcastle Quayside.
 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please stay away from riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinckley of  6.43 mAODN at 9.00 AM on 23/08/2024, with westerly force 6 winds.
Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.
No property flooding is expected.
After the high tide this evening‚ the weather is more settled, and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between, 14:00 and 16:00, Friday 23 August. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.76mAODN at 15:00, Friday 23 August, which is 0.04m above tide tables, wind Force 4, in a south westerly direction.  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 11:30 tomorrow, Friday 23 August.

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at London Bridge is 4.6 mAOD at 05:00 on 23/08/24 and 4.24 mAOD at 17:00 on 23/08/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Custom House (EC3R), Narrow Street (E14), Mayflower and Angel pubs (SE16), Royal Naval College riverfront, the Almshouse Slipway at Crane Street (SE10), Bankside by the Tate Modern (SE1), and Three Mill Island (E3).

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 15 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 23/08/24, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
Heavy rainfall overnight has caused river and lake levels in the area to remain high and cause flooding to low lying land and roads. The forecast is now improving meaning levels with fall throughout today 23/08/2024.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The flood warning has now been removed and there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: The flood alert has now been removed and there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Heavy rainfall overnight has caused river and lake levels in the area to remain high and cause flooding to low lying land and roads. The forecast is now improving meaning levels with fall throughout today 23/08/2024.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Eden
items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding of low lying land and roads. Flooding is possible from 2:00 PM on 23/08/2024 and levels are expected to be at their highest at around 5:00PM.  Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the morning and over the weekend.  More rain is forecast for Sunday evening 25/8/24 into Monday morning 26/8/24.

Areas most at risk include River Eden and its tributaries from its confluence with the River Irthing through Crosby-on-Eden and Carlisle to the Solway Firth at Rockcliffe.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Wampool and Ellen
items.message:
Heavy rainfall in the early hours have caused rising river levels which may lead to flooding of land and road.  Flooding is possible from 6:00 AM on 23/08/2024.  Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the morning and no  flood warnings are expected.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Wampool and Ellen and other watercourses, from Dalston to Maryport including low lying areas around Wigton, Abbeytown, Silloth, Allonby, Aspatria and Dearham.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00am 24/8/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
items.message:
Due to overnight rain lake levels are expected to remain high, causing flooding in the area.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site  .

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with campsite staff.  

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Kent and Bela
items.message:
Heavy rainfall in the early hours has caused rising river levels which may lead to flooding of land and road. Flooding is possible from 6:30 AM on 23/08/2024. Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the morning and no flood warnings are expected.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Kent and Bela and other watercourses, from Kentmere to Silverdale including low lying areas around Staveley, Burneside, Kendal, Milnthorpe and Beetham.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00am 24/8/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rede
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Rede due to heavy rainfall this morning, 23/08/2024. Flooding is still possible at locations near the River Rede and its tributaries, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads in the Otterburn Mill area. 
River levels will rise during Friday afternoon, peaking approximately 15:00 PM and falling throughout Friday evening. We will continue to monitor levels closely, and do not expect flood warnings to be issued. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 19:00 PM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne estuary at Newcastle Quayside, Low Walker, Lower Derwenthaugh Industrial Estate and Willington

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside

items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the Tyne Estuary for the Saturday morning tide, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. We do not expect to see similar impacts for tomorrow’s high tide. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message:
River levels are now falling below flood risk thresholds and there is no longer a threat of flooding, as Storm Lilian passes. Standing water and debris may still remain.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide this evening or throughout the weekend.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Rivers Caldew and Petteril
items.message:
Rising river levels this morning 23/08/2024 may lead to flooding of low lying land and roads. River levels are expected to be at their highest at around 11:45AM.  Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the day and remain dry over the weekend.  Further rain is forecast for Sunday evening 25/8/24 into Monday morning 26/8/24.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Caldew and Petteril from the Lakeland Fells to Carlisle including Cummersdale and Denton Holme in Carlisle.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Irish Sea from New Brighton to Hoylake
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide this afternoon, 23/08/2024.
We do not anticipate the flood alert level to be met during this afternoon’s high tide, but flooding is still possible at low lying land and roads at the head of the Wirral from Hoylake to New Brighton, including parts of Leasowe and Wallasey from 2:30 PM.
The current forecast anticipates the flood alert level will not be met during the high tide in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 24/08/2024. 
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 23/08/2024, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.
